snippet: Some wonder if a directive to hasten death by withholding “ordinary means of nutrition and hydration” should apply to a person who can’t remember it.
abstract: Ethicists, lawyers and older adults are engaged in debate over whether patients who develop dementia should be allowed to end their own lives via withdrawal of food and drink as specified in advance directive; at center of debate is whether a patient can choose to end their life after they become incapable of remembering decisions made while mentally competent.
lead_paragraph: Some wonder if a directive to hasten death by withholding “ordinary means of nutrition and hydration” should apply to a person who can’t remember it.
